content.webTitle: In praise of … taking risks | Editorial

fields.headline: In praise of … taking risks
fields.bodyText: After comparing the dangers of ecstasy and "equasy" (or horse-riding addiction), Professor David Nutt was hounded out as drugs adviser by New Labour stooges who muttered he was nutty in nature as well as name. In fact, he was – albeit provocatively – fulfilling his duty to provide the facts about controlled pharmaceuticals. Today he warns that moral panic about particular pills is hampering important research into the application of psychedelics to psychiatry. Of course, drugs can cause great harm, but our inability to retain perspective on how much damage happens how often reflects a wider failing to reckon rationally with risk. The terror laws watchdog, David Anderson, has relayed that wasps and bees have killed as many Britons as al-Qaida over the last decade. But no insect invites the same horror, and so none has led us to trash ancient liberties. Independent advisers on risk do a great service; inconvenient truths are the sting in their tail.
